item.title: Washington's Threats Forced Greek Shippers to Give Iran Fuel to U.S.
item.description: U.S. threats of legal action and sanctions forced Greek shipowners to surrender Iranian fuel to the U.S. government in recent days, people familiar with the confiscation said.

item.title: U.N. Security Council Rejects U.S. Bid to Extend Arms Embargo on Iran
item.description: The United Nations Security Council rejected a U.S. proposal to extend a five-year ban on the sale of conventional weapons to Iran, leaving Washington isolated on an issue that once drew a broad consensus.

item.title: Protests Grow in Belarus as Opposition Candidate Calls for Election Recount
item.description: Belarus protests are growing as a leading opposition candidate calls for a recount in last weekend’s election, but President Alexander Lukashenko says he won’t be moved.

item.title: Secret Ties Between U.A.E. and Israel Paved Way for Diplomatic Relations
item.description: The diplomatic breakthrough caps more than a quarter-century of deepening—but secret—business and security ties between the two countries that signals a major shift in the geopolitics of the Middle East.

item.title: Schools in Europe Reopen With Little Debate---but More Masks and Distancing
item.description: European countries are pushing ahead with reopening schools despite an uptick in coronavirus cases and new studies suggesting children could be more susceptible to the disease than originally thought.

item.title: Facebook's Hate-Speech Rules Collide With Indian Politics
item.description: A company executive in the vital market opposed a move to ban a controversial politician who staffers concluded had violated hate-speech rules. Some current and former employees allege the ruling party got favorable treatment.
